name: University of Hamburg Business School
description:
We are proud to have been ranked second in Germany in the Wirtschaftswoche Business Research Ranking 2022 and to have been awarded the most prestigious accreditation for international business schools, EQUIS, in 2023.

Our mission: Building on Hamburg‚Äôs history as an international trade metropolis, we develop and teach contemporary approaches to business. In our research and research-based education we focus on evidence-based decision-making. We contribute valuable data-driven insights and foster critical thinking for a sustainable future. 

Our vision is to be a leading Business School in Europe for quantitative and empirical research with high economic and societal impact and for research-based education that develops future leaders to shape a sustainable future. 

Our values are inspired by the Hanseatic ‚Äúhonorable merchants‚Äù who have shaped commerce in Hamburg for centuries. They are recognized as smart and successful business leaders with a global network and a pronounced sense of responsibility for their own companies, for society, and for the environment. Honorable merchants are trustworthy, down-to-earth, and unpretentious. 

‚ñ™ Excellence: We are committed to excellence in everything we do. 
‚ñ™ Impact: We contribute to society by generating innovative, relevant insights based on rigorous research and by educating critical thinkers who make a difference in the world. 
‚ñ™ Responsibility: We uphold and encourage sustainable, socially responsible behavior. 
‚ñ™ Openness: We engage openly with other disciplines, communities and cultures. We embrace diversity in all its forms. 
‚ñ™ Connectedness: We are a collegiate and supportive community that fosters cooperation and gives researchers and students the autonomy to flourish.

Official LinkedIn page of the University of Hamburg Business School

Imprint: 
https://www.bwl.uni-hamburg.de/en/imprint.html

üåèA delegation from Zhejiang Wanli University in Ningbo, China

Last Thursday, a group of about 20 researchers and faculty members came to visit us to learn about the German higher education and scientific systems.

The visit included presentations about the Universit√§t Hamburg and the Business School, as well as a tour of our university museum and a campus tour that highlighted historic and innovative spots, such as the main building and the Tiny House for sustainability. The group also enjoyed a shared lunch.
¬†
We would like to thank Danya Ju from the Brand University of Applied Sciences, Tao Yang, and Gangli Tan from the Professorship of Information Systems and Digital Innovation (Prof. Jan Recker) for organizing and carrying out the visit, as well as for welcoming and guiding the group through the morning.

We‚Äôre grateful for the group's long journey from Ningbo, and we look forward to our continued collaboration! 

Henrik Sattler

A Space for Creative Development üí° 

üöÄ The project ‚ÄúA space for creative development in a sustainable environment‚Äù submitted by e-learning coordinator Dr. Anja G√ºnther has been selected in the call for proposals by the Fund for Innovative Teaching (FIL) as part of the Universit√§t Hamburg‚Äôs Excellence Strategy.

Out of 21 applicants, the idea was among the seven projects awarded, with a grant of around ‚Ç¨25,000. The funding will support us until October 2026 to upgrade a seminar room into a flexible, multi-zone learning environment. 

This new space will enable diverse activities like group work, presentations, and creative workshops, enhancing student engagement and supporting innovative teaching methods. 

It‚Äôs a step forward in creating a more dynamic and responsive learning culture. Prof. Dorothea Alewell, Vice Dean for Education, expressed excitement about how this will foster active participation and new educational formats. 

This initiative aligns perfectly with student feedback from the 2023 Campus Survey, emphasizing the need for better learning, meeting, and collaboration spaces. We look forward to making this a reality and enriching our university community! üå±

üåç Transatlantic Insights: How Politics Shapes Healthcare & Risk Management

This summer, we were honored to host Dr. Meghan Esson and Dr. Cameron Ellis from the The University of Iowa Tippie College of Business at Prof. Petra Steinorth's professorship! In an exclusive interview, they explored critical questions at the intersection of policy, healthcare, and risk innovation.

Key Takeaways:
 ‚û°Ô∏è Policy Pitfalls: Well-intentioned policies can trigger unintended consequences. We have to test these policies rigorously and mustn‚Äôt be afraid to change them even after implementation.
 ‚û°Ô∏è Research Spotlight:
 ‚ñ™Ô∏è Dr. Ellis analyzes how mandatory risk frameworks (e.g., Solvency II) actually impact corporate decisions.
 ‚ñ™Ô∏è Dr. Esson dives into how ‚Äúcharity hazard‚Äù reshapes insurance demand.
 ‚û°Ô∏è Future-Proof Skills: Students should familiarize themselves with two emerging topics in the risk and insurance industry: #ClimateFinance and #AI.

Their work proves why global collaboration is non-negotiable for solving systemic challenges. When Iowa meets Hamburg, perspectives transform.
Beyond research: They loved Hamburg‚Äôs ‚Äústunning architecture‚Äù and ‚Äúincredibly welcoming‚Äù spirit and of course the Miniaturwunderland!

Impossible Founders
¬†
The startup factory Impossible Founders, which is linked to a multi-million euro funding package for startups, was awarded the contract on July 10th by the Bundesministerium f√ºr Wirtschaft und Energie¬†as one of a total of ten flagship startup initiatives in Germany. We are excited to be on board as a business school and part of the Universit√§t Hamburg to support this innovation booster for the city and the metropolitan region, enhancing the innovation hub of Hamburg through startup consulting, courses, and investor networking.
¬†
Approximately 50 million euros have been secured for innovative Hamburg-based startups in the deep tech sector through the scientific application team, consisting of the University of Hamburg Business School, the transfer agency and the university presidium, as well as scientific cooperation partners from Technische Universit√§t Hamburg and Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, with strong support from the Michael Otto Foundation and the Joachim Herz Stiftung. On the corporate side, the project is currently supported by Haspa | Hamburger Sparkasse, the semiconductor manufacturer Nexperia, and the Otto Group.
¬†
Impossible Founders will promote innovative spin-offs from science in Hamburg within the ‚ÄûDeep Tech‚Äú field. The focus is on green technologies and the development of new materials combined with AI and Data Science.
¬†
The startup factory will officially begin operations on October 1st. Its initial location will be the ‚ÄúDigital Hub‚Äù in the Speicherstadt district.
¬†
ü§ù The tasks of the Hamburg startup factory include:
- Providing students and researchers with entrepreneurial know-how 
- Supporting innovative, growth-oriented spin-offs across all phases of company development 
- Contributing to the legal safeguarding of IP transfer with startup-friendly and rapid solutions 
- Establishing connections within the research-intensive economy with application fields for green tech 
- Assisting with investor search 
- Providing access to research infrastructure 
¬†
üôèWe thank all partners and the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy - and look forward to what lies ahead.
Special thanks to: Prof. Michel Clement, Prof. Jetta Frost, Dr. Kea Gla√ü, Prof. Florian Gr√ºner, Prof. Franz Xaver K√§rntner, Jan Henri Kalinowski / Cheftreff

How Can AI Model Causality?

ü§ñ AI is now transforming nearly every aspect of our lives. While machine learning allows us to identify patterns in vast amounts of data, a key question remains: Can AI also help us understand causal relationships? 

Prof. Philipp Bach, who was a Postdoc with Prof. Martin Spindler at the University of Hamburg Business School and has been appointed as assistant professor of econometrics at Freie Universit√§t Berlin since July, is exploring this very challenge. His research focuses on whether AI models can recognize and evaluate causes and effects beyond prediction. This is a critical step toward making informed decisions in healthcare, economics, and other fields.

Understanding causality is essential for making choices, whether it's selecting the best sport for health or analyzing the impact of policy changes like minimum wage increases. But it‚Äôs a complex statistical problem: We often work with sample data and must quantify the uncertainty in our estimates.

üîé To tackle this, Prof. Spindler‚Äôs and Prof. Bach‚Äôs team employs advanced approaches like "double machine learning," combining AI‚Äôs flexibility with rigorous statistical evaluation. Their work also utilizes cutting-edge hardware and neural network architectures to incorporate text and image data‚Äîsuch as analyzing product descriptions and photos in online shopping‚Äîto identify what influences consumer behavior and optimize marketing strategies.
This innovative intersection of AI and causal inference has the potential to revolutionize decision-making across various fields.

https://uhh.de/bcter

Impossible Founders
¬†
The startup factory Impossible Founders, which is linked to a multi-million euro funding package for startups, was awarded the contract on July 10th by the Bundesministerium f√ºr Wirtschaft und Energie¬†as one of a total of ten flagship startup initiatives in Germany. We are excited to be on board as a business school and part of the Universit√§t Hamburg to support this innovation booster for the city and the metropolitan region, enhancing the innovation hub of Hamburg through startup consulting, courses, and investor networking.
¬†
Approximately 50 million euros have been secured for innovative Hamburg-based startups in the deep tech sector through the scientific application team, consisting of the University of Hamburg Business School, the transfer agency and the university presidium, as well as scientific cooperation partners from Technische Universit√§t Hamburg and Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, with strong support from the Michael Otto Foundation and the Joachim Herz Stiftung. On the corporate side, the project is currently supported by Haspa | Hamburger Sparkasse, the semiconductor manufacturer Nexperia, and the Otto Group.
¬†
Impossible Founders will promote innovative spin-offs from science in Hamburg within the ‚ÄûDeep Tech‚Äú field. The focus is on green technologies and the development of new materials combined with AI and Data Science.
¬†
The startup factory will officially begin operations on October 1st. Its initial location will be the ‚ÄúDigital Hub‚Äù in the Speicherstadt district.
¬†
ü§ù The tasks of the Hamburg startup factory include:
- Providing students and researchers with entrepreneurial know-how 
- Supporting innovative, growth-oriented spin-offs across all phases of company development 
- Contributing to the legal safeguarding of IP transfer with startup-friendly and rapid solutions 
- Establishing connections within the research-intensive economy with application fields for green tech 
- Assisting with investor search 
- Providing access to research infrastructure 
¬†
üôèWe thank all partners and the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy - and look forward to what lies ahead.
Special thanks to: Prof. Michel Clement, Prof. Jetta Frost, Dr. Kea Gla√ü, Prof. Florian Gr√ºner, Prof. Franz Xaver K√§rntner, Jan Henri Kalinowski / Cheftreff
¬†
¬†#StartupFactory #DeepTech #ImpossibleFounders #UniHamburg #InnovationHub

Since April 19, 2025, we have had the pleasure of welcoming Prof. Anne Kleffner from the Haskayne School of Business (University of Calgary) as a visiting scholar at the Professorship of Risk Management and Insurance, led by Prof. Petra Steinorth. 

Prof. Kleffner is an internationally renowned expert in the field of risk management and insurance, with a special focus on enterprise risk management (ERM) and insurance for natural disasters.
She shares a long-standing academic collaboration with Prof. Steinorth ‚Äì including joint roles on the editorial board of the Journal of Insurance Issues and the Board of Directors of the American Risk and Insurance Association (ARIA) ‚Äì as well as close alignment in research interests, particularly regarding the role of insurance in healthcare and risk prevention.

Prof. Kleffner will be conducting research in Hamburg through June 30 and is looking forward to continued academic exchange and experiencing life in northern Germany.

üé∂ New Study Reveals How Smart Speakers Are Shaping The Music Streaming Market

Smart speakers like Amazon Echo and Google Home are no longer just gadgets ‚Äî they are transforming how we consume music. A recent study led by Levent Uyar from the University of Hamburg Business School uncovers how these devices increase music streaming time and deepen user loyalty to specific streaming services.
¬†
üìä Key findings from our representative survey of 1,518 German music listeners show:
‚Ä¢ Users with smart speakers listen to over 20 hours of music weekly ‚Äî significantly more than non-users (16 hours).
‚Ä¢ 73% of smart speaker owners subscribe to paid music streaming services, compared to just 39% of those without.
‚Ä¢ Device and streaming service ecosystems are closely linked: Amazon Echo users favor Amazon Music Unlimited, Google speaker owners more often use YouTube Music.
¬†
Levent Uyar, Research Associate at the Professorship of Marketing & Media under Prof. Michel Clement, adds:
‚ÄúOur study results reveal close connections between smart speaker devices and their streaming services. This dynamic raises fascinating questions about ecosystem lock-in, as well as the opportunities and challenges for the global music streaming market.‚Äù
¬†
As smart speakers become key platforms for music streaming, they may reshape market competition and influence which content reaches listeners. This evolving landscape presents exciting opportunities and challenges ‚Äî and calls for continued research.

Join the conversation on the future of music streaming! 
¬†
Read more about this study and find the open access link in the comments. 

üì∏ Portrait: Boris Rostami-Rabet 

#SmartSpeakers #MusicStreaming¬†#AmazonEcho #GoogleHome

üì£¬†Job alert: Call for Applications!

The call for applications for the second cohort of the #HCHE's #DFG Research Training Group will initially start with two doctoral positions, with more to follow this fall. Graduates of a master's degree program in economics can apply until June 6, 2025. The two positions are advertised for dissertation topics "Staffing regulations in the long-term care market" and "Adoption of new technologies in the long-term care market" and begin on October 1, 2025.
With the Research Training Group "Managerial and economic dimensions of health care quality," the HCHE has been training doctoral students in a structured doctoral program in the field of health economics since 2023. The program funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) - German Research Foundation offers high-quality academic training, including a comprehensive course program, participation in research seminars, workshops, and international conferences, and the opportunity to conduct research abroad. 

Information can be found on our website: https://uhh.de/cke5v

AIDAR - an AI-powered music industry startup on the road to success üé∂ 

The Business School accompanies startups from the idea to the foundation and the first milestones - and often beyond. AIDAR is an example of such a startup that we interviewed at the very beginning of its foundation. AIDAR was founded to make artist scouting in the music industry smarter and more efficient. 

About six months have now passed since the company was founded. We asked the founders of the AI start-up from the music industry, Dr. Janek Meyn and Caspar Zinn, about their most important challenges and experiences. 

1Ô∏è‚É£  Challenges: 
‚≠ê  The great freedom to make decisions, which doesn't exist in the corporate world and which takes some getting used to. 
‚≠ê The fact that both founders have never worked in the music industry. But through intensive networking, feedback and conversations with the target group, the pieces of the puzzle came together. 
¬†
2Ô∏è‚É£ Learnings: 
‚≠ê From their studies, the founders took away the structured analysis of problems and data as well as the development of solution approaches. And learned that decisions often have to be made much more quickly in practice. 

üçÄ Janek, Caspar, good luck on the road ahead!

üí° New Study on Crises: How Some Companies Can Grow During Tough Times
¬†
Prof. Jan Recker, Nucleus Professor for Information Systems and Digital Innovation at the University of Hamburg Business School, Prof. Frederik von Briel from the University of Queensland, and Prof. Per Davidsson from J√∂nk√∂ping International Business School explain with their new theory why major societal crises that are detrimental for most companies can lead to exceptional growth for some. Their work, published in the prestigious journal "Academy of Management Review," analyzed the literature on major societal crises since the Industrial Revolution and compared the developmental paths of companies that emerged or grew during these crises.
¬†
The authors suggest that crises, which are detrimental to most companies and society, typically nevertheless substantially benefit a few firms through increased demand, positive press coverage, and favorable resource redistribution.
¬†
üí¨ ‚ÄúCrises amplify the demand for offerings that mitigate the circumstances of the crisis‚Äîlike video conferencing systems during lockdowns‚Äîwhich favors companies that quickly and prominently position themselves as core relief providers.‚Äù, explains Prof. Recker. ‚ÄúThis creates a self-reinforcing spiral of demand expansion, positive reporting, and new acquisition potential, which creates significant growth potential for these few firms.‚Äù

üåü Winners of the Teaching Award üåü
¬†
We are proud to announce the inaugural Teaching Award recognizing the best-rated courses in our Business School. The award will be presented each semester by the Management Board across various categories, including compulsory and elective lectures, based on student evaluations.
¬†
Each semester, students participate in anonymous evaluations for all courses offered at the Business School using a standardized questionnaire. They provide their insights on teaching and learning objectives, exam requirements, contributions of instructors, and additional comments through open-ended questions. Each evaluation allows students to rate the overall course and the instructor's performance on a scale from 1 (poor) to 5 (excellent). Julia Diana Lenk is a doctoral student at the Professorship of Marketing and Branding under Prof. Dr. Henrik Sattler. At the end of September 2024, she took part in a 6-month research stay at INSEAD in Fontainebleau near Paris. After her return in March, she spoke to us about her experiences.

üí´ The most important insights: 

1Ô∏è‚É£  The research stay brought many new contacts with professors, doctoral students and postdocs whose heart beats for Academia. 

2Ô∏è‚É£  It was interesting to learn more about how she linked her research focus in marketing on individual characteristics and diversity dimensions with her interest in ecolabeling.

3Ô∏è‚É£  As a current research fellow, Julia is supported by a scholarship from the Joachim Herz Stiftung for interdisciplinary business administration, which she used to fund her research stay‚Äîan inspiring opportunity that may also be valuable for other early-career researchers and certainly worth exploring.

üöÄ DASHH: Collaboration between the DESY and our business school 
¬†
We're thrilled to announce the launch of our new research project, ‚ÄúAI-Powered XFEL Laser Operations: Boosting Uptime with Language Models,‚Äù which kicked off on March 1, 2025. This groundbreaking initiative, a collaboration between the Professorship of Data Science at the University of Hamburg Business School and Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, aims to develop an AI-driven assistant over the next three years to enhance the maintenance and troubleshooting of complex laser systems.
¬†
üéá Large-scale X-ray synchrotrons and free-electron lasers (XFELs) depend heavily on intricate optical laser systems. Failures in these systems can lead to costly downtime, even with a dedicated laser operator on standby. Recognizing that no individual can know every detail of each laser system, the project will offer a targeted solution.
¬†
The team is harnessing advanced large language models (LLMs) to process extensive technical documentation, logbook entries, and control data, ultimately assisting laser operators in troubleshooting and maintenance tasks. This innovative assistant promises to improve both the efficiency and accuracy of problem-solving, while also streamlining technical documentation and providing performance metrics for data-driven decision-making.
¬†
Funded by the Data Science in Hamburg - HELMHOLTZ Graduate School for the Structure of Matter (DASHH), the project is led by Prof. Anne Lauscher (University of Hamburg Business School), Dr. Ingmar Hartl, and Dr. Henrik T√ºnnermann, both from DESY. 
¬†
Our newly recruited PhD student, Afshin Karimi will focus on practical implementation: "As part of this innovative project, I am using large language models to analyze complex technical documentation and logbook entries, supporting laser operators in identifying issues and optimizing maintenance processes. The goal is to leverage AI to increase the uptime and efficiency of the laser systems, ultimately enhancing scientific productivity at DESY." 
¬†
As Prof. Lauscher states: ‚ÄúThis project marks a further step towards a future in which Generative Artificial Intelligence helps to optimize research infrastructures in order to advance scientific discoveries.‚Äù
¬†
#AI #DataScience #DESY #LaserTechnology #XFEL #LLM #Helmholtz
üì∏ (c) DESY

¬†
Martin Spindler, Professor of Statistics with Applications in Business Administration, is the new academic director of the interdisciplinary Industrial Engineering and Management degree program, which is offered in cooperation with Hochschule f√ºr Angewandte Wissenschaften Hamburg (HAW Hamburg) and Helmut-Schmidt-Universit√§t/Universit√§t der Bundeswehr Hamburg. He succeeds Prof. Guido Voigt, Professor of Logistics and Supply Chain Management, to whom we extend our gratitude for his significant dedication.
¬†
To mark the start of this new role, we spoke with him about his plans. Here is an excerpt from the conversation:
¬†
1Ô∏è‚É£ When would you recommend young people study Industrial Engineering and Management?
üí¨ If they want to understand the interplay between technology and management and prepare for responsible positions.
¬†
2Ô∏è‚É£ How do you assess the job prospects for industrial engineers?
üí¨ We are in a time where technological understanding is becoming increasingly important. Therefore, the prospects are very good.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Is there a relevance between your own research fields and the interdisciplinary program in Industrial Engineering and Management?
üí¨ In a current project, we have been collaborating with ams-OSRAM to examine how methods of Causal Machine Learning can be used to reduce scrap in chip production. It doesn‚Äôt get more industrial engineering than that.
¬†
‚≠ê We wish Prof. Spindler all the best in his new role!

ü§ñ How do we create an AI that represents cultural diversity?  
¬†
More and more companies and private individuals are using generative artificial intelligence such as ChatGPT or Dall-E. However, the data on the basis of which the results are generated does not reflect the entire global population equally. Prof. Anne Lauscher and Carolin Holtermann at the University of Hamburg Business School are researching how this leads to distorted representations - and what countermeasures can be taken.

üëâ Key findings from their work:
- The data used to train models often comes from privileged groups and common languages such as English.
- As a result, less commonly spoken languages and cultures are often completely underrepresented. There are clear biases in the generation of images: Images generated with languages such as Hindi or Finnish reproduce stereotypes or do not show people at all.

¬†üí°¬†The aim of the research is to develop more inclusive AI models that better represent the diversity of cultures and languages worldwide. Innovative measurement methods will be used to identify systematic weaknesses in order to improve the quality of the data and results.

The impact of AI on our everyday lives is growing - so it is crucial to make these technologies fair and equitable. 

üëâ See the first comment for the link to the full interview.

#LLM #AI #ChatGPT #DallE

üëâ Public Lecture Series "Management in Foundations" at the Universit√§t Hamburg

In collaboration, the University of Hamburg Business School, B√ºrgerStiftung Hamburg, and Stiftungsb√ºro Hamburg are organizing the second series of lectures "Management in Foundations" for the summer semester of 2025. 

Over the course of seven lecture dates, distinguished speakers from foundations and the University of Hamburg will provide practical and scientifically grounded insights on key topics in foundation management. The public lecture series offers students of the university as well as foundation practitioners valuable insights into the diverse fields of work within charitable foundations.

"We are excited to have attracted foundation experts with such a wide range of topics for the lecture series, thus training interested young talents," says Prof. Petra Steinorth, Dean of the University of Hamburg Business School. She is pleased about the participation of many renowned foundations, including the Alfred Toepfer Stiftung F.V.S., B√ºrgerStiftung Hamburg, Hanns R. Neumann Stiftung - HRNS, Hans Weisser Stiftung, Haspa Hamburg Stiftung, Joachim Herz Stiftung, K√∂rber-Stiftung, Stifterverband f√ºr die Deutsche Wissenschaft, and ZEIT STIFTUNG BUCERIUS.

Co-Initiator of the lecture series, Prof. Michel Clement from the University of Hamburg Business School, adds: "The enormous societal challenges require close cooperation between academia and foundations to train talents in a way that enables them to tackle these challenges. Therefore, I am very happy to offer the topic 'Management in Foundations' as a lecture at the University of Hamburg together with representatives from Hamburg foundations."

The first public lecture will take place on Thursday, April 3, 2025, from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM (official start time at 4:15 PM) in lecture hall ESA-A in the main building of the University of Hamburg.

üì¢ Guest researcher Taylor Graciano: Economic consequences of widowhood

We look back on a successful research exchange with Taylor Graciano, a PhD candidate from the The University of Georgia and designated Assistant Professor at New Mexico State University, who was a guest of Prof. Petra Steinorth at the Professorship of Risk Management and Insurance.

During her research stay from December 2024 to January 2025, Graciano explored the economic consequences of widowhood‚Äîan innovative research field with significant macroeconomic implications of $11 billion annually in the U.S. alone.

"International networks are very important for making research more tangible‚Äù, says Taylor Graciano. ‚ÄúCollaboration (‚Ä¶) opens my eyes to education systems that work differently‚Äî and that makes me a better scholar." 

This collaboration has not only enriched our research agenda but also provided our students with valuable international perspectives: Graciano actively supported teaching in the course "Principles of Risk Management and Insurance."

Taylor‚Äôs research on preventive healthcare for widows and widowers contribute significantly to the foundation for evidence-based health policy. 

üôè Taylor, thank you for all of your input and inspiration.

üëâ Read the full interview: https://lnkd.in/eqK_kA5H

‚ñ∂Ô∏è New Vice Dean for Research and Graduate Education at the University of Hamburg Business School 

We are excited to announce that on February 1, Malte Fliedner, Professor of Operations Management, has taken on the role of Vice Dean for Research and Graduate Education. He succeeds Nicole Ratzinger-Sakel, Professor of Auditing and Corporate Accounting, who has done an outstanding job over the past two years. Prof. Fliedner has been Head of the Graduate School and a member of the Doctoral Board since March 1.

‚≠ê His motivation:¬†
‚ÄúThe University of Hamburg Business School has an extremely attractive research profile that aligns very well with the university's strategy and the scientific clusters in the city of Hamburg. Being able to contribute to strengthening this profile is already an exciting task. Additionally, we are training excellent early career researchers, and it is extremely motivating for me to be able to positively influence the career paths of these young scientists.‚Äù

üëâ Goals: He aims to ensure that our research profile remains innovative and diverse while promoting the networking of our young researchers with national and international partners.

üëâ Research Focus: His research centers on innovative logistics and mobility systems, in which algorithmic decision-making methods are critical for efficient management.

üëâ Advice for Early Career Researchers: ‚ÄúEngage with topics that truly interest you, rather than being swayed by short-term trends.‚Äù

Last week, the University of Hamburg held its annual Unitag, welcoming high school students to explore various degree programs and university life. 

The Bachelor in Business Administration program and the interdisciplinary Industrial Engineering and Management degree program had booths, with professors, program coordinators, and current students available to assist visitors. Both programs also hosted a 45-minute session in the Audimax, offering in-depth insights into their curricula. For Business Administration, Professor Wolfgang Br√ºggemann and student Olivia Schubert spoke to a full audience, while the interdisciplinary Industrial Engineering and Management program was presented by Professors Guido Voigt and Martin Garbrecht.

üí¨ Prof. Voigt summarizes: ‚ÄúThe interest from the students was tremendous, and the auditorium was well filled. It‚Äôs wonderful to see so many young people, regardless of gender, excited about the exciting opportunities this program offers.‚Äù

‚≠ê Study over 25 years: brands remain relevant for companies ‚≠ê 

Since 1999, PwC Deutschland and Professor Henrik Sattler, along with his team, have been regularly examining the significance of brands. In the current and fifth study, particular emphasis has been placed on how sustainable corporate governance influences brand communication and consumer purchasing behavior. The analysis is based on insights from 207 executives across various industries.

The study highlights that consumers are increasingly valuing authentic sustainability communication. Companies must recognize this trend and adapt their brand strategies accordingly to minimize switching behavior and build trust.

üëâ Thus, brands are not only key to business success but also important players on the path to greater sustainability. 

üëÄ For all details regarding the brand study and the full report, visit the PwC Germany website. Markenstudie 2024 - PwC

JSIS 2024 Honourable Mention Award for Jan Recker and co-authors üèÖ 
¬†
Jan Recker, professor of Information Systems and Digital Innovation, and his co-authors received an Honourable Mention Award 2024 from The Journal of Strategic Information Systems (JSIS) for their paper "Configuring alliance portfolios for digital innovation". 
¬†
The paper explores the question: Are alliances a promising strategy for firms to become more digital and innovative? 
¬†
The team analyzed data from millions of patent applications from 550 U.S. firms and found that large and exploratory alliances help firms create more digital innovation, while international alliances and alliances with competitors do not. They also learnt that firms need to strategically plan their alliances differently depending on whether they want to patent digital innovations or other innovations.

Congratulations to all authors: Theresa Sophie Bockelmann, PhD, Karl Werder, Jan Recker, Julian Lehmann, Prof. Dr. David Bendig
